output.conclusion: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of wireless communication principles and technologies, equipping students with the knowledge to analyze, design, and implement wireless systems.
output.introduction: Welcome to Wireless Communication! This course delves into the fundamental concepts and technologies behind modern wireless systems. We will explore modulation techniques, channel characteristics, multiple access methods, and network protocols.

chapters.description: Overview of wireless communication systems, history, applications, and challenges. Frequency spectrum allocation and regulations.
Path loss, shadowing, fading (multipath propagation), and Doppler shift. Channel models for different wireless environments.
Free space propagation, reflection, refraction, diffraction, and scattering. Impact of terrain and obstacles on signal strength.
Amplitude Modulation (AM), Frequency Modulation (FM), and Phase Modulation (PM). Performance analysis and applications.
Amplitude Shift Keying (ASK), Frequency Shift Keying (FSK), Phase Shift Keying (PSK), and Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM). Constellation diagrams and bit error rate (BER) analysis.
Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) and its applications in wireless systems. Introduction to MIMO modulation.
Frequency Division Multiple Access (FDMA), Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA), Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA), and Space Division Multiple Access (SDMA).
Aloha, Slotted Aloha, Carrier Sense Multiple Access (CSMA), and CSMA with Collision Avoidance (CSMA/CA).
Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access and Single-Carrier Frequency-Division Multiple Access. Their applications in 4G and 5G networks.
Cellular networks, ad hoc networks, mesh networks, and sensor networks. Characteristics and applications of each topology.
IEEE 802.11 (Wi-Fi), Bluetooth, Zigbee, and cellular protocols (GSM, CDMA, LTE, 5G). Protocol architectures and functionalities.
Security threats and vulnerabilities in wireless networks. Encryption techniques (WEP, WPA, WPA2, WPA3) and authentication protocols.
